sn22.95:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ayojjhā on the bank of the Ganges river.
sn22.95:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn22.95:5.1: “Mendicants, suppose this Ganges river was carrying along a big lump of foam.
sn22.95:5.2: And a person with good eyesight would see it and contemplate it, examining it carefully.
sn22.95:5.3: And it would appear to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:5.4: For what substance could there be in a lump of foam?
sn22.95:5.5: In the same way, a mendicant sees and contemplates any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior;
sn22.95:5.7: And it appears to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:5.8: For what substance could there be in form?
sn22.95:6.1: Suppose it was the time of autumn, when the rain was falling heavily, and a bubble on the water forms and pops right away.
sn22.95:6.2: And a person with good eyesight would see it and contemplate it, examining it carefully.
sn22.95:6.3: And it would appear to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:6.4: For what substance could there be in a water bubble?
sn22.95:6.5: In the same way, a mendicant sees and contemplates any kind of feeling at all …
sn22.95:6.7: And it appears to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:6.8: For what substance could there be in feeling?
sn22.95:7.1: Suppose that in the last month of summer, at noon, a shimmering mirage appears.
sn22.95:7.2: And a person with good eyesight would see it and contemplate it, examining it carefully.
sn22.95:7.3: And it would appear to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:7.4: For what substance could there be in a mirage?
sn22.95:7.5: In the same way, a mendicant sees and contemplates any kind of perception at all … examining it carefully. And it appears to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial. For what substance could there be in perception?
sn22.95:8.1: Suppose there was a person who needed heartwood. Wandering in search of heartwood, they’d take a sharp axe and enter a forest.
sn22.95:8.2: There they’d see a big banana tree, straight and young and flawlessly grown.
sn22.95:8.3: They’d cut it down at the base,
sn22.95:8.4: cut off the top, and unroll the coiled sheaths.
sn22.95:8.5: But they wouldn’t even find sapwood, much less heartwood.
sn22.95:8.6: And a person with good eyesight would see it and contemplate it, examining it carefully.
sn22.95:8.7: And it would appear to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:8.8: For what substance could there be in a banana tree?
sn22.95:8.9: In the same way, a mendicant sees and contemplates any kind of choices at all …
sn22.95:8.11: And they appear to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:8.12: For what substance could there be in choices?
sn22.95:9.1: Suppose a magician or their apprentice was to perform a magic trick at the crossroads.
sn22.95:9.2: And a person with good eyesight would see it and contemplate it, examining it carefully.
sn22.95:9.3: And it would appear to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:9.4: For what substance could there be in a magic trick?
sn22.95:9.5: In the same way, a mendicant sees and contemplates any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior;
sn22.95:9.7: And it appears to them as completely void, hollow, and insubstantial.
sn22.95:9.8: For what substance could there be in consciousness?
sn22.95:10.1: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with form, feeling,
sn22.95:10.7: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn22.95:10.8: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
